text: Chevrolet debuted the Malibu over 50
years ago the nameplates ups and downs
include 14 years of retirements
beginning in the early 80s generation
nine has a look worthy of its Tony
California namesake during my week with
it people mistook it for an Audi and
Lexus yes even wearing the bowtie Car
and Driver recently did a comparison
test that included Camry and Accord
Malibu bested them but was not the
overall winner that would be Mazda 6
proving that popularity may not be the
best reason to choose a car maybe price
is key beginning at 22,500 bucks with 10
airbags and keyless ignition this
top-of-the-line premiere model swells to
30 for 3 is tested the only major option
missing is a sunroof so adaptive cruise
control auto braking with pedestrian
detection and a pretty decent sound
system are along for the ride heated in
cool leather chairs to Malibu doesn't
miss a trick
including
a balanced ride quality one thing you'll
notice right off the bat the chassis
structure very rigid
there is no adjustable suspension though
sport mode no comfort mode and none of
those are needed the Chevy engineers
pretty much nailed the driving dynamics
there are three ways to motivate a
Malibu a hybrid powertrain a 1.5 liter
turbocharged four-cylinder and this
2-liter turbo for 250 horsepower and 258
pound-feet of torque has plenty of power
the larger engine gets eight speeds but
an awkward way to select them manually
over two inches longer now Malibu has
shed nearly 300 pounds
zero to 60 takes just over six seconds
it easily caves freeway on-ramps this
two liter is everything you'd want an
engine to be smooth and powerful but
there is a price to be paid
it averages about five miles per gallon
less than the 1.5 liter at least I'm
seeing Uncle Sam's rated average of 26
miles per gallon the hybrid version is
supposed to average forty-six mpg and
word is the smaller 4-cylinder is very
refined just less pet Malibu is
available with the system called teen
driver basically a parent programs the
key and then among other things it
offers up sort of a report card on how
your kid has been driving it also
controls certain aspects of the audio
system no seat belts no tunes
my mother-in-law have this system
shoppers should check out the interior
color palettes they changed the
character of the cabin the control
layout is clean with just the right
amount of hard buttons there's a 4G LTE
hotspot too
the interior is nicely detailed
competitive in class though clearly this
is from an industrial plants not a
natural one apple carplay and android
auto simplify smartphone operations
still smart drivers keep use to a
minimum i'll hop off my soapbox now the
outgoing malibu not exactly known for
its generous backseat room it's amazing
what the addition of 1.3 inches of
legroom will do cushions are comfy looks
like con Edison set up a substation here
many competitors have heated seats in
back sorry not available in Malibu
other than that passengers should be
comfortable for long road trips to the
beach a proper measurement metric is
importance generally cars in Malibu is
class all about six or seven packs of
stuff remember these days spare tires
can be optional the boo is not as useful
as a hatchback or crossover but it is
practical that includes a big boot
I brought eight packs out and they all
fit just keep valuables away from the
hinge arms clearly General Motors
listened to owners and perhaps more
importantly those who did not buy the
outgoing model the biggest obstacle
keeping this car from gaining market
share is simple brand loyalty to other
automakers wise shoppers will surf into
a Chevy store to check what out though
Malibu has hit high tide in a fiercely
battled segment
